Yes, Germany is the problem and is unlikely to cease being a problem, because no nation willingly surrenders advantageous terms of trade, which is what Germany and the other nations of the core enjoy relative to the nations of the periphery. So it is unlikely that Germany will offer or accede to reforms in the euro that will correct the fundamental flaws in the euro--as identified in the work of scholars, such as Lerner, Mundell, Kennan, and McKinnon--and thus eliminate its large current account surpluses by mechanism that distribute those surpluses to other nations which have current account deficits, as happens here in the U.S., when the federal government distributes surpluses to other regions of the U.S. which need investment and/or emergency assistance.

That is why I expect the euro to eventually breakup, as has been the fate of other common currency areas that were composed of individual sovereignties. Thus, only prospect for the long-term success of the euro is the establishment of a supreme sovereign in the Eurozone. But the prospect for that happening peaceably is highly unlikely, as there is no nation in the EU or even in the Eurozone which willing to assent to any sovereignty, except on its own terms, and this is especially true of France and Germany, each of whom is only willing for more Europe on its terms. And lately, with the election of Hollande, France and Germany are at odds over the terms of more Europe. So the long-term prospects for the euro are bad.

Climate chaos is the physical and moral equivalent of war. Today's example the central Philippines, which looks like Hiroshima and Nagasaki after The Bomb. Many coastal cities worldwide will be similarly destroyed by the rising sea, killer storms and drought in coming centuries.

Some climate scientists predict the coming catastrophe will continue for 100,000 years even if we stop emitting greenhouse gasses now, which is impossible. Some of my most intelligent, highly educated friends speak about climate change as if it were still something that might happen, not something that will happen. Government agencies chatter about climate change "adaptation," and "resiliency" instead of telling people our options will be limited when things get really bad. People assume that if cities like Las Vegas and Phoenix water can be piped in from ever more distant places, e.g., new dams in the Pacific Northwest, or melting glaciers in Alaska and northern Canada.

If we really grasped the fact that massive numbers of people worldwide are going to die because during this long catastrophe, we would mount a Manhattan Project type effort to convert to renewable, non-atomic forms of energy, implement an orderly decrease in the human population to a level compatible with the carrying capacity of global ecosystems, and invent a steady state economic system that far less ruinous than end stage capitalism. Unfortunately, none of this seems likely, at least in the near term.

Among the few phrases in the short communique, the key ones are "comprehensively deepening reform" and "crossing the river by feeling stones".

The reference to "comprehensive" reforms fits with the billing in the Chinese state media that this meeting of the top Chinese Communist Party officials will result in significant reforms under the new president and premier during their decade in power.

However, the details as to how these reforms will be implemented. are lacking.

Permitting the market to play a "decisive" role in the economy has emerged as a message in the state media.

This sums up the aims of the Chinese leaders, which is to introduce more market forces into the economy. It would be key to achieving the "breakthrough" reforms that were discussed in the "383 plan that was circulated by the government's top think tank beforehand.

The 3 "breakthrough" reforms involved reforming capital markets, labor in the form of improving social welfare, and land.

Basically, the factors of production all need reform and much of it requires raising productivity to support growth.

The Tea Party and the disappearance of Republican moderates have not yanked congressional Democrats to the right.  Congressional Dems have moved left of where they had been from the 1970s to the 1990s, a result of the defeat of Democratic moderates in the election of 1994.  The Congressional delegations of both parties swung that year--Republicans to the right, Democrats to the left.  But Democratic presidential candidates remained moderate, as we see with both Clinton and Obama, and even with Al Gore who ran and lost(?) in 2000.  The reason?  Because a left wing Democratic presidential candidate cannot win, any more than a far-right Republican like Cruz cannot win.  .Presidential candidates, barring a national crisis like another 9-11-- will remain planted firmly in the center.   All of which means that Elizabeth Warren might get nominated but can't win a presidential race.  Hillary can.

At the national level, within the Democratic party, there is now a discussion about the inevitability of the Clinton candidacy, precisely for the reasons Professor Edsall reminds us of. I've been asking myself whether, this time around, seven years after the near collapse of our banking system, how Hillary Clinton will be received by a public that, according to the polls, is very unhappy about the fact that not one single banker was tried - much less jailed. This time, will her long-time association with Wall Street Liberals hurt her candidacy? Will the public accept a left of center Clinton campaign on its face, or will she have to do a lot of convincing? Those questions will only be answered, with the passage of time, and if well-known, serious candidates enter the primary against Clinton.

I don't necessarily see a good fight, between the right wing of the Democratic party and its left as a bad thing. The party is about due for a realignment. The last five years' worth of Tea Party politics in the states and in Congress, the disintegration of the GOP left, and congressional obstruction have yanked the congressional Democrats far to the right. It's high time it doubled back to the place it has always been.

Some of you guys must have not paid attention during American history class in high school. The fact that in the Senate every state gets two seats, regardless of the state's population, and that in the House, Representatives represent relatively equal blocks of population, reflects a compromise made in the 1790s between more populous and less populous states. It is part of the design of our governement, specifically to reduce the power of states with big populations, so that the smaller population states were willing to join the union.

In addition, the fact that overall there were more votes for Democratic house candidates than Republican house candidates is irrelevant, if the Democratic votes are concentrated in more urban areas. Note that this has almost nothing to do with gerrymandering; it has to do with the fact that urban areas tend to be more homogenous in their political party voting than less urban areas. Winning a house seat with any more than 50.1% of the votes cast is a waste of votes, unfortunately for Democrats. No Republicans are going to support proportional voting schemes for divying up house sets within each state, since it was never done like that in the past.

"..The USA is the last holdout with market-priced medical care not only because of any inherent conservative or free market ideology. Rather, as the wealthiest nation that ever existed we are the last ones who can afford it. Switzerland was one of the last advanced economies to abandon market-priced medical care. It is arguably a greater bastion of conservatism than the USA. Switzerland's women were not granted the right to vote until 1971.

The reason that no nation, including the wealthiest can allow markets to set the prices of medical care indefinitely is that demand for medical care is inelastic. Demand for a good or service is inelastic if a percentage increase in price results in a smaller percentage decrease in the quantity demanded. Basic economics tells us that sellers facing inelastic demand will continuously raise prices until prices reach the elastic portion of the demand curve. Consequently in every developed country in the world, all goods or services with inelastic demand have their prices regulated by government. Medical care in the USA being the only exception.

Health care is one of the very few things for which the sellers face inelastic demand. The prices of all other goods and services facing inelastic demand in the USA are regulated by government. Retail electricity service providers face inelastic demand. Consequently, their prices are strictly controlled by all governments worldwide, including the USA...."

If there is no means testing the admin cost should be closer to 1% than 10%.  Medicare's exact admin burden is debated but is widely acknowledged to be under 5%.  Social Security's very well administered program has miniscule costs as a percentage of benefits paid.

The economics of this would be fascinating. If we assume $10,000 per person, I would have just increased my income by 33% to $40,000 after my son's birth last week. That's not great, but a lot of families live on less than $40,000 today.

Personally, I think the US would immediately see an economic boom as the poorest citizens suddenly had an increase in disposable income. At the same time, our savings rate would plummet and the income threshold when people start really saving would go up as they paid out more in taxes. Then, I think we'd see some substantial inflation as retailers figure out how much more they can charge. Ultimately, the poorest would have more stability, which is great, but nothing more.

Personally, I like the welfare state and believe in the safety net, but our goal should be to have people transition out of the safety net. That doesn't mean coercively pushing people out. It means assistance for people who are struggling.

I don't see the point of the government charging me, say, $11,000, and giving me $10,000 back. The cost of administering the program for me would take something out of that $11,000, meaning some smaller amount would go towards redistribution. Those few dollars add up for the xx% of people who would pay out more than they receive. That money is pure waste.

Finally, I'm no debt scold, but there's no way we would fully fund that initiative. The debt is growing faster than the economy, which is unsustainable in the long-run.
